title: Cat. 69  Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Diocletian, A.D. 294/305

<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Diocletian  
A.D. 294/305, issued by Diocletian  
Gold; diam. 1.8 cm; 5.27 g  
Mint: Trier  
Obverse: Head of Diocletian right, laureate  
Inscribed: DIOCLETIANVS P F AVG  
Reverse: Jupiter stands right, brandishing thunderbolt at anguipede giant Porphyrion  
Inscribed: IOVI FVLGERATORI; PT (in exergue)  
RIC VI 20; axis: 6:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Mr. Roger Trienens, 1996.350

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">When Diocletian (r. A.D. 284–305) beat out his rivals for the position of emperor in A.D. 284, he knew he had to make some changes in order for Rome—badly battered after a half-century of civil war and invasion—to survive. No longer could a single emperor rule from Rome. From 286 Diocletian shared the government and defense of the state with a “caesar,” a junior partner, Maximian—not really a novelty, since many emperors had associated their successors in their rule. But in 293 he made a gamble: both he and Maximian would carry the title Augustus, while two more officers would be appointed as caesars. With an augustus and caesar in the East and another pair in the West, usurpers and barbarians could be kept in control—or so he hoped. In order to maintain the upper hand, Diocletian would retain the title Jovius that he had adopted in 286, while Maximian would still be Herculius. Thus the Tetrarchy was formed. It did not survive past his reign, but it and other reforms did buy the empire some much-needed time. The “thundering Jupiter” on the reverse is shown destroying one of the fin-footed Giants who tried to destroy Olympus. Diocletian was definitely battling gigantic foes: invasions, civil strife, an uncontrollable military, and devastating inflation among them.

The currency reforms of Diocletian began in 293 with the restoration of the aureus to 60 aurei to the Roman pound, or about 5.34 grams; our coin falls comfortably within the target weight. This had some effect on slowing inflation. The mint mark PT identifies the mint as Trier (Latin: Treveri).  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Diocletianus Pius (“dutiful”) Felix (“happy”) Augustus.

Mattingly, “Jovius and Herculius,” p. 131.

It had fallen badly since Aurelian’s reforms of c. 272: see cat. 67, Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Aurelian; Estiot, “Later Third Century”; Harl, Coinage in the Roman Economy, pp. 149–52.

See also cat. 70, Argenteus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Diocletian.
